title: 104_hr2026
content:
The "George Washington Commemorative Coin Act of 1996" authorizes the minting of $5 gold coins with specific specifications. The coins will weigh 8.359 grams, have a diameter of 0.850 inches, and contain 90 percent gold and 10 percent alloy. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Gold for minting will be obtained by the Secretary from other provisions of law. The "George Washington Commemorative Coin Act of 1996" specifies that the coins minted under this Act should embody George Washington. The design must include the coin's value, the year "1999", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with specific organizations and reviewed by a committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting May 1, 1999, with minting authority ending on November 31, 1999. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales will include a $35 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be paid to the Mount Vernon Ladies' Association to support the preservation of George Washington's home and educational efforts about him. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee of payment from a depository institution. Payment of Surcharges: No surcharge proceeds for coin sales shall be paid to the Association until all numismatic costs are recovered and audited financial statements show private funds raised equal to or greater than the maximum surcharge amount. Annual audits are required. The Association must undergo annual audits by an independent public accountant for all payments received from surcharges on coin sales until the funds are fully expended or placed in trust. Minimum audit requirements include reporting on the Association's financial activities. The Association must undergo annual audits to report the amount of payments received from surcharges on coin sales, the amount expended from the surcharges, and whether all expenditures were for authorized purposes. The Association must ensure separate accounting for surcharge proceeds and submit an audit report to the Treasury Secretary within 90 days of the fiscal year end. The Association may use surcharge proceeds to pay for required audits and the Treasury Secretary can waive certain subsections for the Association. The Association must provide books and records to receive surcharge payments. The Association must provide books, records, and workpapers to the Inspector General or Comptroller General upon request. No surcharge proceeds can be used to compensate agents or attorneys for influencing coin legislation. The Association is not allowed to use surcharge proceeds to compensate agents or attorneys for influencing coin legislation. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on September 17, 1996.
